INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 (1) (a) (ii) Intervention standards and
Section prohibitions.
Description (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
2

(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a youth on
any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 12/22/22, youth was crying and then went up to a staff member and
smacked staff member across the face and pulled on their face mask.
Staff member shoved youth hard, causing youth to fall to the ground.
Youth is non-verbal and cannot speak to the incident.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A is non-verbal youth. This consultant viewed Youth A’s
interactions at the facility on December 28, 2022. Youth A was
spinning in circles around this consultant and then showed this
consultant his room. Youth A appeared to be in positive spirits and
interacting with staff members on the unit.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on December 28,
2022, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Detective. Staff 2
reported on December 22, 2022, Youth A was having a behavioral
episode because he was not allowed into the staff office area. He
reported he walked into the milieu and sat down on the chair. Staff 2
reported Youth A likes to twirl in circles when walking around the milieu
and was doing that at first. Then Youth A rushed up to him, pulled his
face mask and slapped him. Staff 2 reported he attempted to block
Youth A from swinging at him by putting his arm up when Youth A was
rushing towards him. He reported he never extended his arm or pushed
Youth A with his arm. Staff 2 reported Youth A did fall to the ground on
his butt when he ran against Staff 2’s arm that was up. He reported
Youth A got up right away and Staff 2 moved out of the way of Youth A.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1 suggested Staff 2 take a break and she would
supervise so that is what he did. He reported Youth A has been
struggling since he got his teeth pulled and his normal interventions of
food or listening to music is not helping console his behavior. Staff 2
reported he was Youth A’s one to one staff member and typically his
assigned staff when he works. He reported earlier that day, Youth A
had bit him which he has not done in a while and thinks the teeth
pulling had something to do with this change in behavior. Staff 2
reported he never pushed or shoved Youth A. He reported, “I would
hope everyone at this job is to never push a kid because we are to here
to help them.” Staff 2 reported he has been trained to keep physical
distance from the youth due to boundary needs and behaviors. He
reported with Youth A he is quick to make a change and run up on a
staff. Staff 2 reported he was trained to help keep physical space for
safety, to use the block method. He reported he has never had to do a
physical restraint at the facility.
4

Staff 1/ Complainant Source was interviewed via phone on
December 22, 2022, and face to face at the facility on December
28, 2022, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and Detective. Staff
1 reported on December 22, 2022, Youth A was crying in the milieu for
about 15 minutes. She reported this is typical behavior for Youth A and
staff are to continue to supervise him. Staff 1 reported during this time,
herself, Staff 2, Supervisor 1, and Supervisor 2 were all in the milieu
area with Youth A. She reported Youth A walked up to Staff 2, pulled
down his face mask and slapped Staff 2 on the face. Staff 1 reported
Staff 2 was sitting down when this happened, and he reacted by taking
one hand and shoving Youth A. She reported Youth A then fell to the
ground on his butt and did not hit his head, back or elbows. Staff 1
reported Youth A continued to cry and walk in circles around the milieu.
She reported Youth A did not express that he was in any pain. Staff 1
reported after the push happened, she suggested for Staff 2 to take a
break because he seemed frustrated with Youth A due to his crying.
She reported Staff 2 then went into another area and she talked with
administration about the concerns of Staff 2 pushing Youth A. Staff 1
reported staff are trained that they cannot push the youth, even when
they are frustrated. She reported Youth A is on one to one staff due to
being non-verbal and aggressive behaviors towards himself and other.
She reported it is typical to have Youth A crying for a half hour or more
at a time. Staff 1 reported she looked Youth A over and did not see any
marks or bruising on him. She reported she feels Staff 2 had the
intentions to get Youth A away from him when he pushed him. She
reported the appropriate response should have been for Staff 2 to get
up and walk away from the situation. Staff 1 stated the staff have been
taught to switch out Youth A’s one to one staffing at times because of
his high needs so they do not get frustrated. Staff 1 reported there was
no other youth or staff around when the incident occurred.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 28, 2022, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and
Detective. Supervisor 1 reported he was over in the milieu talking with
Supervisor 2 when the incident occurred on December 22, 2022. He
reported Youth A was spinning in circles and crying which is typical for
Youth A’s behavior. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 2 was sitting in the
milieu and Youth A ran up to him with his arms extended. He reported
he saw Staff 2 put his arm up to block Youth A from hitting him in the
face. Youth A ran into Staff 2’s arm and he fell to the ground on his own
force from running up to him. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A got up
from the ground and continued to spin in circles. He reported this is
typical behavior and Youth A actually has a helmet due to him spinning
around the room and running into things. Supervisor 1 reported he
trained Staff 2 and has no concerns with his ability to perform his job as
a direct care staff member. He reported Staff 2 has a good relationship
4

with Youth A and does not believe Staff 2 pushed Youth A to the
ground. Supervisor 1 reported he is the facilities’ certified Handle with
Care restraint trainer and from what he saw was Staff 2 performing a
block and did not even extend his arm to push Youth A to the ground.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 28, 2022, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and
Detective. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A recently had 6 teeth removed
and has been more agitated due to the pain and not being able to
express it. She reported Youth A’s baseline is typically him crying,
whining, and banging his head. She reported on December 22, 2022,
she was talking with Supervisor 1 and then saw Youth A was on the
floor. She reported she does not know how Youth A ended up on the
floor as she was not paying attention. Supervisor 2 reported she did not
think anything off it because Youth A will spin around and fall on the
ground every so often on his own. She reported Staff 1 did talk to her
about the concerns of Staff 2 pushing Youth A to the ground.
Supervisor 2 reported she works with Staff 2 on a regular basis and has
not seen him become frustrated with the youth, especially Youth A. She
reported Staff 2 will take a break when he needs it.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 28, 2022, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and
Detective. Supervisor 3 reported he is the direct supervisor for Staff 2
and reported he is a great worker. Supervisor 3 reported he is working
with Staff 2 on taking breaks on shift especially when working with
Youth A due to Youth A’s high needs. He reported he has had to do
these reminders with all of the staff because of Youth A’s higher level of
needs and that the team should be working on tag teaming the one to
one supervision. Supervisor 3 reported he has never heard concerns of
Staff 2 having poor interactions with the youth and was surprised to
hear there was a report of Staff 2 pushing Youth A. Supervisor 3
reported he has noticed Youth A likes to be around Staff 2 more than
other staff due to his calming nature.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on December
28, 2022. Youth B reported he has lived at the facility for about three
months and reported he feels safe. He stated the staff treat the youth
well at the facility and has never seen a staff member push or hurt
another youth. Youth B reported he can become frustrated with Youth A
sometimes because he cannot verbally express his needs. He reported
he has hit Youth A before because he was annoyed with him but stated
he has never seen staff hit Youth A. Youth B reported he likes working
with Staff 2.
4

Youth A’s Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on
December 22, 2022. Youth A’s Foster Care Worker reported Youth A
has been placed at the facility since March 2022. She reported Youth A
is nonverbal and has autism. Youth A’s Foster Care Worker reported
Youth A gets triggered easily displays behaviors such as hitting his
head due to frustration and not being able to verbalize. She reported
she has not had any concerns with the facility’s ability to care for the
youth. Youth A’s Foster Care Worker reported the facility has been
great with following the one to one supervision and communicating with
the worker.
Conference call was held with MDHHS Worker on January 17,
2023. MDHHS worker reported there are no findings to their
investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility incident report dated December 22, 2022 completed by
Supervisor 1- Incident report was consistent with Supervisor 1’s
interview.
- Facility incident report dated December 22, 2022 completed by
Staff 1- Incident report was consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
- Developmental Adolescent Residential Treatment Restraint
Policy- Prohibited Behavior Management Techniques at the facility
includes corporal or physical punishment including spanking, hitting,
pinching, slapping, or hair pulling. Staff 1 signed off stating he
understood the policy on August 23, 2022.
- Youth A’s facility file- A collection of the past three months incidents
reports were gathered and showed Youth A has a history of self-injuring
and assaulting staff when upset.
- Facility Injury and Bruise Chart for Youth A- On December 21,
2022, at 10pm the day before the incident it was noted there was
bruising on his lower left section on Youth A’s left buttock. On
December 22, 2022 at 6 am before the incident occurred staff
completed an injury/ bruise chart on Youth A which noted a scratch on
his head and self-inflected bite marks on his arms. At 10pm another
injury/bruise chart was completed which noted a faded healing bruise
on the lower right section on Youth A’s left buttock.
- Youth A’s Individual Safety and Calming Plan dated November
14, 2022- This safety plan notes Youth A has the precursors to
aggression includes crying, whining, pulling, pushing or kicking staff.
4

Pro-active strategies staff can use is waiting out the behavior while
keeping him safe and blocking the aggression.
-Human Resource (HR) file and Training Log for Staff 2- Staff 2 has
no disciplinary actions noted within his HR file. Staff 2 is up to date on
all required training. Staff 2 completed the required restraint training,
“Handle with Care” on 08/23/22 and 08/30/2022.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as both Staff 2 and Supervisor 2
noted Staff 2 had put his arm up to block Youth A from physically
hurting Staff 2. Youth A fell to the ground due to his own force and
continuation of spinning in circles. Supervisor 2 is the certified
behavioral management trainer for the facility and was the one to note
a proper block was used by Staff 1.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was provided to the facility in how to best support
Youth A’s high needs and to make sure that staff are switching out
being Youth A’s one to one staffing. Staff 2 was provided training on
compassion fatigue and having check ins with his supervisor for added
support.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy.
It is recommended that the current license status be continued.
